required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Improvement of Intraoperative Neuromonitoring of Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve
clinical_study.official_title: The Improvement of Intraoperative Neuromonitoring of Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve During Thyroid Surgery

lead_sponsor.agency: Kaohsiung Medical University Chung-Ho Memorial Hospital

clinical_study.source: Kaohsiung Medical University Chung-Ho Memorial Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: Objectives: The use of neuromuscular blocking agent may interfere with the function of intraoperative neuromonitoring (IONM) in thyroid surgery.

detailed_description.textblock: An enhanced neuromuscular-blockade (NMB) recovery protocol was investigated in a clinically applied during thyroid neural monitoring surgery. In as subsequent clinical application study, 60 patients who underwent thyroidectomy with IONM followed an enhanced NMB recovery protocol- rocuronium 0.6 mg/kg at anesthesia induction and sugammadex 2 mg/kg at operation start. Train-of-four (TOF) ratio was used for continuous quantitative monitoring of neuromuscular transmission.

primary_outcome.measure: sugammadex 2 mg/kg allows effective and rapid restoration of neuromuscular function suppressed by rocuronium

arm_group.description: rocuronium 2 effective dose at anesthesia induction sugammadex after skin incision and before extubation (total 2 mg/kg iv)
standard general anesthesia protocol (1 effective dose of rocuronium at anesthesia induction)

intervention.description: standard general anesthesia protocol with sugammadex

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients undergoing intraoperative neuromonitoring of recurrent laryngeal nerve during thyroidectomy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with a history of significant cardiac, pulmonary, hepatic, or renal disease, body mass index <18.5 or >35, chronic drug or alcohol abuse

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Kaohsiung Medical University Chung-Ho Memorial Hospital
